questions.question: Concurrency Control is required to manage simultaneous operations in a multi-user database system.
In a multi-user system, only one user can access the database at any given time.
Concurrent execution should be performed in an interleaved manner to maintain consistency.
The two main operations in a database transaction are READ and WRITE.
A Lost Update problem is categorized as a W-R (Write-Read) Conflict.
The Dirty Read Problem is also known as the Temporary Update Problem.
The Inconsistency Problem is related to the Unrepeatable Read Problem.
A Lost Update occurs when a record is updated by two different transactions at the same time.
In the Lost Update example, transaction Tx reads the value of A as $250 at time t1.
In the Lost Update example, transaction Ty reads $300 at time t3 because Tx has not yet updated the value.
A Dirty Read occurs when a transaction accesses updated data before the original transaction rollbacks.
In the Dirty Read example, transaction Tx adds $100 to account A.
In the Dirty Read example, the value for Ty remains $350 even though Tx rolled back to $300.
Timestamp-Based Protocols are a method used for Concurrency Control.
Validation-Based Protocols are NOT used in DBMS Concurrency Control.
Concurrency control is only necessary for single-user systems.
The Lost Update problem leads to incorrect data and an inconsistent database.
Multi-version schemes are one way to handle concurrency control.
Concurrency control management is also applicable to index structures.
A 'Write-Write Conflict' is associated with the Dirty Read Problem.
